title: BUSTED: The most blatant insurance scams uncovered by fraud police
text:
BUSTED: The most blatant insurance scams uncovered by fraud police BUSTED: The most blatant insurance scams uncovered by fraud police THE lengths insurance cheats go to in an effort to con money out of firms and raise the cost of premiums for the rest of us have been revealed by the City of London's special fraud department. PUBLISHED: 12:56, Mon, Jul 13, 2015 | UPDATED: 13:49, Mon, Jul 13, 2015 GETTY The most brazen insurance frauds have been revealed 
From non-existent injuries to fake thefts, fraudsters use a variety of far-fetched stories to get underserved payouts, but firms have warned that they are cracking down on false claims. Insurers uncovered an average 350 frauds worth £3.6million every day in 2014, according to the Association of British Insurers (ABI). The trade body said that motor fraud was the most common scam, with detected cases up 12 per cent on 2013 and valued at £835 million.However, the number of liability insurance frauds detected jumped by a huge 75 per cent with a value of £330 million. James Dalton, ABI’s director of general insurance policy, said: “The vast majority of customers are honest, and should not have to pay for the fraudulent minority. "Insurance cheats are now more likely to get caught than ever before, whether they are making a dishonest claim or lying when applying for cover to get a cheaper premium, and face long-lasting and serious consequences. "As well as the possibility of serving a custodial sentence, they will find it difficult to obtain vital financial services such as mortgages and loans, future job prospects are likely to be adversely impacted and family relationships suffer. Here are the most blatant scams that have been uncovered... A man who died from 'brain fever' - was later found alive with a new name 
In a scam reminiscent of the 'canoe couple' who faked the death of John Darwin, Anju Kuamr told five insurers that her husband Sanjay Kumar had died from 'brain fever' to try to collect more than £1million in payouts. Mrs Kumar, from Watford, said that Mr Kumar had been cremated in India on 25 November 2011 after falling ill on a visit. But insurers could find no records of Mr Kumar being treated and the person with whom Mr Kumar was supposed to have stayed with in India denied knowing him.It was established that Mr Kumar was in debt and that pressure to pay creditors had been building.Detectives then found that Mrs Kumar had used a Western Union transfer to send £1,500 to her husband in India on 27 November 2011 – two days after she alleged he had died – and that he collected it.After Mr Kumar flew back to the UK from India under the fake name of ‘Sanjay Vig’ on 17 August 2012, he was then arrested and later jailed for two-and-a-half years. City of London Police Sanjay Kumar's fake death certificate 
A supermarket slip-up In December 2012 Waheed Iqbal deliberately 'slipped' on a wet bag in Lidl to make a £10,000 bogus injury claim. The 36-year-old from Bradford claimed he had suffered head and body injuries. But the shop’s CCTV footage showed showed Mr Iqbal carefully staking-out the aisle, placing his shopping trolley next to the bag and then gradually easing himself to the floor before flagging down a fellow shopper. 
The con-artist was wheeled out of Lidl to an ambulance but later asked the paramedics to stop before they reached the A&E. He then got out of the vehicle unaided and went straight back to the store to speak to the manager about recording the incident.The next day he went to A&E complaining of pain and vomiting after he had reportedly hit his head.After the fraud was uncovered Mr Iqbal received a 10-month suspended prison sentence. A 'disabled' postman filmed at a music festival Postman Belangeni Musumbu claimed an accident at work had left him unable to dress himself, work or drive in an effort to get hundreds of thousands of pounds in an insurance payout. But the 46-year-old from London was later seen on a blog about the Rainforest World Music Festival playing the guitar. Mr Musumbu was then filmed lifting boxes out of his car after driving and shopping. 
He was jailed for 18 months and ordered to pay back £24,527. Facebook catches out ring of deception David Frederick Hammond was tried to con his insurer out of £20,000, by claiming his fiancée’s engagement ring and a gold bracelet had been stolen while on holiday in Brazil. But months later a picture of his future wife wearing the ring appeared on Facebook. He received a six month suspended jail sentence. Related articles
